item.title: @KordingLab This seems like a pretty coarse-grained analysis that effectively shows that low-pass spatial filtering is good for denoising (i.e. the low-frequency spatial modes account for most of the variance in the data).
item.description: @KordingLab This seems like a pretty coarse-grained analysis that effectively shows that low-pass spatial filtering is good for denoising (i.e. the low-frequency spatial modes account for most of the variance in the data).
item.content:encoded: @KordingLab This seems like a pretty coarse-grained analysis that effectively shows that low-pass spatial filtering is good for denoising (i.e. the low-frequency spatial modes account for most of the variance in the data).

item.title: @KordingLab I'm surprised they didn't go for the jugular and try to quantify how the eigenmodes differ between the purely spatial model and the connectome model. Surely the true modes must come from the graph mixture of local connectivity + the connectome (small world). What am I missing?
item.description: @KordingLab I'm surprised they didn't go for the jugular and try to quantify how the eigenmodes differ between the purely spatial model and the connectome model. Surely the true modes must come from the graph mixture of local connectivity + the connectome (small world). What am I missing?
item.content:encoded: @KordingLab I'm surprised they didn't go for the jugular and try to quantify how the eigenmodes differ between the purely spatial model and the connectome model. Surely the true modes must come from the graph mixture of local connectivity + the connectome (small world). What am I missing?

item.title: @PessoaBrain @DrBreaky @CVakalopoulos I explicitly don't say that and think that our addiction to causation is misguided. I just say very loudly that a correlational study should not make causal claims. So correlational study with causal claims in the discussion will get me to say something.
item.description: @PessoaBrain @DrBreaky @CVakalopoulos I explicitly don't say that and think that our addiction to causation is misguided. I just say very loudly that a correlational study should not make causal claims. So correlational study with causal claims in the discussion will get me to say something.
item.content:encoded: @PessoaBrain @DrBreaky @CVakalopoulos I explicitly don't say that and think that our addiction to causation is misguided. I just say very loudly that a correlational study should not make causal claims. So correlational study with causal claims in the discussion will get me to say something.

item.title: @tyrell_turing @KordingLab I am sorry but what brain activity? the attentional focus on the methods is a red herring. What the results imply is that the dynamics of fMRI BOLD signals has little to do with neural dynamics. I am ok with that conclusion.
item.description: @tyrell_turing @KordingLab I am sorry but what brain activity? the attentional focus on the methods is a red herring. What the results imply is that the dynamics of fMRI BOLD signals has little to do with neural dynamics. I am ok with that conclusion.
item.content:encoded: @tyrell_turing @KordingLab I am sorry but what brain activity? the attentional focus on the methods is a red herring. What the results imply is that the dynamics of fMRI BOLD signals has little to do with neural dynamics. I am ok with that conclusion.

item.title: @BoninLab @KordingLab I agree that it is more accurate to say that this tells us about the dynamics of BOLD - and the relationship to activity dynamics might be complicated. But, what makes you say that these results show that BOLD has little to do with neural activity?
item.description: @BoninLab @KordingLab I agree that it is more accurate to say that this tells us about the dynamics of BOLD - and the relationship to activity dynamics might be complicated. But, what makes you say that these results show that BOLD has little to do with neural activity?

item.title: @tyrell_turing @KordingLab Is there is any BOLD dynamics not captured? fMRI BOLD is like the pixel values of a camera pointed at an extremely large symphonic orchestra where by strings and keys have subpixel resolution. The camera will reveal rhythm and notes onset, not the mechanics of music generation.
item.description: @tyrell_turing @KordingLab Is there is any BOLD dynamics not captured? fMRI BOLD is like the pixel values of a camera pointed at an extremely large symphonic orchestra where by strings and keys have subpixel resolution. The camera will reveal rhythm and notes onset, not the mechanics of music generation.

The camera will reveal rhythm and notes onset, not the mechanics of music generation.

item.title: @tyrell_turing @KordingLab I am actually serious. Yes fMRI BOLD correlates with neural activity. This may have some value in clinical applications, I can't judge. But for investigations of neural dynamics, the precious money should be invested in large-scale human electrical recordings or other techniques.
